text: <@U12452RAP> - I responded to your question in <#C29512UHF|fabric-sdk-node-dev>  as well
but my basic logic was that the SDKs are for building clients and therefore enrollment should be simple and also that I don't think that clients should be overriding things set by the COP admin
until it is proven that this is needed by clients, I went with exposing the minimal config required
Thanks <@U0PB67X4K> I will follow that in python SDkK

text: fabric-cop’ers: can we please help <@U195M30MD>… ? It’s the second day I see these questions in various channels.

Yes, I got it. I closed the <#C1J0BM448|membership-services> channel back in the day.
it would be helpful to understand if that error means user not configured in membersrvc or there’s something else I’m missing
So this should be “the” place for these. TBH, the good ol’ `memberservc` did/does not have the best, most intuitive, g-d bless them error messages.

Some of us have been very very strict with the fabric-cop (v1) error messages over the last few months, to tackle that. So I hear you when you tell me that you don’t always know what a certain error means.
I am in the middle of something, but if this is not resolved, then I’ll get more into it. I suspect that something is missing from the DB (that would be a “row”…)
DO you have that in your YAML file ?
[You see, I’m getting into it already - please don’t answer, I gotta run ;-)]
Joking. That would be just my first thing to check.

ok the Java SDK (the test I’m running is PeerClientTest) uses a user called User1, which is not in the membersrvc.yaml (and the first question would be why). But if I change it with one from membersrvc.yaml (jim for example) I get the same exact output
ok small progress on that, I deleted /var/hyperledger/production and the keystore on the client, then re ran the tests, and finally got past that error

```
vp0_1         | 16:47:16.383 [peer] ProcessTransaction -> ERRO 213 ProcessTransaction failed to verify transaction Certificate has not been signed by a trusted authority. [x509: certificate signed by unknown authority (possibly because of "x509: ECDSA verification failure" while trying to verify candidate authority certificate "eca")]

```

attachments.fallback: [January 9th, 2017 7:27 AM] jonathanlevi: I think that this component (fabric COP) requires a LOT of testing… we have merged a lot, pretty quickly, but we need to see it working.
attachments.text: I think that this component (fabric COP) requires a LOT of testing… we have merged a lot, pretty quickly, but we need to see it working.

text: <@U11MANG9G|jonathanlevi> pinned a message to this channel.

attachments.fallback:
[January 9th, 2017 6:57 AM] keithsmith: 1) API simplification - <https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-1462>
   a) Delete idp package; all API structs go into api package.
      - api/net.go contains structs defining everything that goes over the network
        between the client and server.
      - api/client.go contains structs defining I/O to the client library objects
   b) Simplify object hierarchy in lib to be only Client, Identity, & Cert;
      signer, temporalSigner, and verifier are consumed in Cert.
      Identity object has:
         GetECert() (Cert, error)
         GetTCerts(req *GetTCertBatchRequest) (*GetTCertBatchResponse, error)

2) TCert option 2 (depends on #1)
   - The GetTCertBatchRequest struct in api/client.go has a bool field:
       DisableKeyDerivation bool
     If this is true, then option 2 is used.  This is the only change to the client.
     The rest is handled by the client library code.
   - The impl of GetTCertBatch in lib/identity.go calls BCCSP to generate a key-pair for
     each tcert in the batch.  It then sets the array of public keys in the
     GetTCertBatchRequestNet struct defined in api/net.go and sends the request to the server.
   - The server generates a CSR for each public key, signs them, and returns the array of certs.
     This is done in cli/server/tcert.go and requires relatively minor change.
     After we get the attribute values (no change), if there is an array of public keys, we
     fork off to separate code to generate the CSRs and sign them.  The only thing we call lib/tcert.go
     code for is to get the extensions which go in the CSR.  Each of these CSRs should be identical
     except for the value of the public key, so that should be the only thing in the loop.

3) BCCSP COP integration (slightly dependent on #1, but could merge)
   a) Into CFSSL
      - CFSSL pull request has been submitted (see <https://github.com/cloudflare/cfssl/issues/711>)
      - rebase/refactor <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/3679/> on top <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/3735/>
   b) Into COP itself
      - lib/tcert.go rewritten using BCCSP APIs (also on top of <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/3735/>)
        Is this done in <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/3679/>?

4) CLI Improvements - <https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-1170>

5) Store/retrieve tcert root prekey in DB - <https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-1561>

6) Helpme improvements
   b) endpoint whitelist - <https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-1555>
   c) register with password - <https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-1473>

7) Documentation
   - Update the readme docs.  Not sure when this needs to be done.
     See <https://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/latest/Setup/Chaincode-setup/#option-2-docker-for-mac-or-windows> for example
   - Swagger doc for REST APIs.  Given api/net.go, can we use <https://github.com/go-swagger/go-swagger> to auto generate swagger doc?
     (depends on #1)
   - User's guide in fabric-cop/README.md.  See <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/3727/>
   - Developer's guide to include code overview
attachments.text:
1) API simplification - <https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-1462>
   a) Delete idp package; all API structs go into api package.
      - api/net.go contains structs defining everything that goes over the network
        between the client and server.
      - api/client.go contains structs defining I/O to the client library objects
   b) Simplify object hierarchy in lib to be only Client, Identity, & Cert;
      signer, temporalSigner, and verifier are consumed in Cert.
      Identity object has:
         GetECert() (Cert, error)
         GetTCerts(req *GetTCertBatchRequest) (*GetTCertBatchResponse, error)

2) TCert option 2 (depends on #1)
   - The GetTCertBatchRequest struct in api/client.go has a bool field:
       DisableKeyDerivation bool
     If this is true, then option 2 is used.  This is the only change to the client.
     The rest is handled by the client library code.
   - The impl of GetTCertBatch in lib/identity.go calls BCCSP to generate a key-pair for
     each tcert in the batch.  It then sets the array of public keys in the
     GetTCertBatchRequestNet struct defined in api/net.go and sends the request to the server.
   - The server generates a CSR for each public key, signs them, and returns the array of certs.
     This is done in cli/server/tcert.go and requires relatively minor change.
     After we get the attribute values (no change), if there is an array of public keys, we
     fork off to separate code to generate the CSRs and sign them.  The only thing we call lib/tcert.go
     code for is to get the extensions which go in the CSR.  Each of these CSRs should be identical
     except for the value of the public key, so that should be the only thing in the loop.

3) BCCSP COP integration (slightly dependent on #1, but could merge)
   a) Into CFSSL
      - CFSSL pull request has been submitted (see <https://github.com/cloudflare/cfssl/issues/711>)
      - rebase/refactor <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/3679/> on top <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/3735/>
   b) Into COP itself
      - lib/tcert.go rewritten using BCCSP APIs (also on top of <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/3735/>)
        Is this done in <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/3679/>?

4) CLI Improvements - <https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-1170>

5) Store/retrieve tcert root prekey in DB - <https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-1561>

6) Helpme improvements
   b) endpoint whitelist - <https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-1555>
   c) register with password - <https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FAB-1473>

7) Documentation
   - Update the readme docs.  Not sure when this needs to be done.
     See <https://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/latest/Setup/Chaincode-setup/#option-2-docker-for-mac-or-windows> for example
   - Swagger doc for REST APIs.  Given api/net.go, can we use <https://github.com/go-swagger/go-swagger> to auto generate swagger doc?
     (depends on #1)
   - User's guide in fabric-cop/README.md.  See <https://gerrit.hyperledger.org/r/#/c/3727/>
   - Developer's guide to include code overview

text: I have just spent a day and a half with Greg, just trying to start the cop server without it crashing.
I am totally fine with software/new code that has just been developed and requires testing.

I just don’t belong to the school of thought of `if it compiles then it is ready for production/deployment`. All I am/we are asking is that we test stuff before we declare success/done/ready.

Just to re-iterate:
We really need to test this stuff, before we recommend it to others. The status of this project is `under development`, for a reason. Please let's not underestimate this crucial part of the SDLC.

As we have just seen, the fact that some code has passed the compilation step with a few tests - is not enough. You/we need to really check stuff before it is shipped. You can’t tell, unless you really use it.
